<snip>
> I'm actually adding the class attribute directly on the link itsel=
f

fect
> CSS rendering at all. =A0I can either take advantage of that class n=
ame
> in CSS, or add multiple classes (e.g. <a href=3D"..." class=3D"jobs
>=
 important">Job Listing</a>).
</snip>

I see. So you're decorating links in=
 both cases, but using REL for
imparting the meaning of the *link*, and CLA=
SS for imparting the
meaning of that *data* at the other end of the link ar=
c.

Is that really necessary? I mean to ask. Can do you have several
exampl=
es where these two bits of information (meaning of the link,
meaning of the=
 data at the other end) are particularly divergent?

mca

m/blog/
